title: In Syria, the fight to preserve evidence of Assad regime's crimes
summary: Several organizations are calling on the rebels not to destroy evidence of the regime's crimes, partly to help in the search for the thousands of people who disappeared in Assad's prisons.

title: Macron aims to name prime minister 'within 48 hours'
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron met with party leaders on Tuesday for talks on the formation of the new government.

title: Adèle Haenel tells director Christophe Ruggia to 'just shut up' after he denies child abuse in court
summary: The French actress, who quit filmmaking after saying the industry turned a blind eye to sexual abusers, says Christophe Ruggia groomed and assaulted her when she was between 12 and 14.

title: Israel takes advantage of Syrian regime's fall to extend its control of strategic areas
summary: Claiming to aim to guarantee its own security, Israel has deployed troops beyond the UN-monitored buffer zone with Syria. While 'temporary,' according to Israel's Foreign Minister, the move raises several questions.

title: Syrian rebels name Mohammed al-Bashir head of transitional government as he calls for 'stability and calm'
summary: Mohammed al-Bashir had previously headed the rebels' so-called Salvation Government in northwest Syria.

title: 'The Paris AI summit will act against the risks and for the benefits of AI'
summary: Anne Bouverot is tasked by the Elysée Palace with organizing an AI summit in February bringing together companies, NGOs and 100 heads of state.

title: Thousands told to flee as wildfire tears through Malibu, California
summary: California Governor Gavin Newsom said the state had already secured a Fire Management Assistance Grant from the Federal Emergency Management Agency to assist with the response on Tuesday.

title: In Syria, the beginnings of an evacuation of Russian bases
summary: A ballet of cargo planes discreetly takes the most important equipment to Russia, while Moscow negotiates with the new government in Damascus in the hope of maintaining a military presence in Syria.

title: Suspect in the killing of UnitedHealthcare's CEO shouts toward reporters while entering courthouse
summary: Luigi Nicholas Mangione, 26, emerged from a patrol car for his Tuesday court appearance, spun toward reporters and shouted something partly unintelligible referring to an 'insult to the intelligence of the American people' while deputies pushed him inside.

title: Crisis at Northvolt: The fall of a symbol of Sweden's green reindustrialization
summary: The bankruptcy of the Swedish battery giant casts a shadow over the economic future of northern Sweden, which had hoped for revival through the environmental transition of industry.

title: Senior Russian official confirms Assad in Russia, Syrian rescuers ask Russia to pressure him into providing secret jail maps
summary: A senior Russian official confirmed to NBC news that Bashar al-Assad was transported to Russia after rebel forces swept into Damascus on Saturday. Syria's White Helmet rescuers on Tuesday called on Russia to pressure former president Assad into providing maps of secret jails and lists of detainees as they race against time to release prisoners.

title: Biden says Trump's economic plan will be a 'disaster'
summary: Biden, on Tuesday, said US consumers would pay the price for tariffs Trump has vowed to slap on Mexico, Canada and China. Trump then announced Andrew Ferguson as the next chair of the Federal Trade Commission, Jacob Helberg as the next undersecretary of state for economic growth, energy and the environment, and Dan Bishop as deputy director for budget.

title: Le Pen and Mélenchon caught out by past support for Bashar al-Assad
summary: In recent years, both French politicians have made supportive remarks about the dictator. Marine Le Pen saw him as a bulwark against jihadism, while Jean-Luc Mélenchon was driven by visceral anti-imperialism aimed at America.

title: Europe debates fate of Syrian refugees
summary: Several countries, including France and Germany, have announced that they are suspending decisions on asylum applications from Syria. Far-right parties, meanwhile, have re-opened a political and legal debate on refugee deportation.

title: Israeli army says it has 'struck most of the strategic weapons stockpiles' in Syria
summary: An Israeli army statement said the IDF had struck Syria some 480 times in the past two days, targeting strategic military sites.

title: Israel's PM Netanyahu rejects corruption charges as 'ridiculous'
summary: Benjamin Netanyahu was in court on Tuesday, facing charges of bribery, fraud and breach of public trust in three separate cases.

title: US disburses $20 billion Ukraine loan backed by profits from Russian assets
summary: The loan, thanks to interest earned on frozen Russian assets, forms a part of the G7's aid to Ukraine.

title: Argentina rape case against French rugby players dropped
summary: An Argentine court, in the city of Mendoza, Argentina, dismissed rape charges against Hugo Auradou and Oscar Jégou, two French international rugby players. The prosecution had argued for the case to be dropped.

title: What will France's climate be like at +4°C?
summary: The national weather service has published forecasts on the temperatures and precipitation that the country is likely to experience in 2030, 2050 and 2100. These projections will serve as the basis for the national climate change adaptation plan.

title: South Korea's national police chief and Seoul's top officer detained over enforcement of martial law
summary: The development comes hours before the main liberal opposition Democratic Party submits a new motion to impeach Yoon on the martial law introduction. The party said it aims to put the motion on a floor vote on Saturday. Yoon avoided impeachment last Saturday after most governing party lawmakers boycotted a floor vote in the National Assembly.

title: 'Trump is good if not for the economy, at least for the stock market'
summary: 'Le Monde' New York correspondent Arnaud Leparmentier writes that since Trump's election, Wall Street has continued to soar, with his arrival in power expected to lead to a financial orgy worthy of the 1920s.

title: In Syria's Saydnaya prison, the shattered hopes of families of the missing
summary: Thousands of people have flocked to the prison since it was liberated, attracted by rumors that there were still prisoners in the compound's basements. On Monday night, rescue workers completed their search, revealing 'no unopened or hidden areas within the facility.'

title: The Biden administration's moral corrosion
summary: By pardoning his son Hunter before Donald Trump's inauguration, Joe Biden has flouted the principles he claimed to uphold, such as the separation of executive and judicial powers, as well as respect for the rule of law, irreparably tainting the end of his term in office.

title: The baffling success of Vienna's Christmas markets
summary: The Austrian capital hosts 14 markets in the run-up to the festive season. Tourists are expected to flock to sample a drink with a strange recipe and stroll among the stalls offering products that are not always local.

title: Ghassan Salhab: 'Lebanon has never been a nation'
summary: In an interview with Le Monde, the Lebanese filmmaker says his country's situation is the result of colonialism and decolonization.

title: The best pictures from the Nikon Comedy Wildlife Photography Awards
summary: Each year, prizes are awarded for photographs of the animal world that are sure to make you smile. The technical quality and the prowess of the shots are of course commendable, too.

title: Musée Cognacq-Jay in Paris reopens, a few days after a robbery
summary: The Parisian institution claims to have complied with all security standards. The number of in French museuls thefts has been falling since 2023.

title: Prosecutor seeks prison sentence for director Christophe Ruggia in trial for assaulting Adèle Haenel
summary: The prosecutor asked for a five-year sentence for the filmmaker, three of which suspended and two with an electronic bracelet, over accusations he sexually assaulted the actress when she was a minor. The verdict is set for February 3.

title: 'Spend more on European defense? But the coffers are empty!'
summary: Andrius Kubilius, the new European commissioner for defense, is calling for €500 billion and a 'big bang' for the military spending and equipment. The extent of this challenge is coming to light both at NATO and within the EU, Le Monde columnist Sylvie Kauffmann writes.

title: Trump defends choice of Kushner for France envoy
summary: Speaking to French magazine 'Paris Match', Donald Trump defended his choice to appoint Charles Kushner, the father of Donald Trump's son-in-law Jared, as US envoy to France.

title: Covid-19: Study breaks down which Western European countries responded best
summary: Countries that took measures to restrict social contact before waiting for their hospitals to become overwhelmed saved more lives and better preserved their economies, according to a ground-breaking study by the Institut Pasteur published on Monday.

title: France's budget: What's in the 'special law' that 'guarantees the continuity of national life'?
summary: Examined in a cabinet meeting on Wednesday, the minimalist bill averting a shutdown will be put to a vote on December 16.

title: Assassination of UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson reveals flaws in American society
summary: After his arrest on Monday, December 10, Luigi Mangione, the alleged killer of the CEO of the leading health insurance company in the US received many messages of support.

title: Defiant Netanyahu makes first appearance before Israeli courts at corruption trial
summary: Accused of corruption, fraud and breach of trust, the Israeli prime minister intends to use his trial as a political platform.

title: Who is Lauriane Nicol, activist journalist at Adèle Haenel's side?
summary: Creator of the online media outlet Lesbien Raisonnable, Lauriane Nicol has been at Adèle Haenel's side ever since the actress revealed that she had been sexually assaulted by director Christophe Ruggia, who is on trial.

title: Syria: Survivors of Assad regime's dungeons speak of horror
summary: Ibn al-Nafees hospital, in northern Damascus, now has the difficult task of caring for the broken men freed from the Assad regime's hellish prisons. Its doctors have never seen such psychological distress. Their families, for their part, have been desperately trying to locate their loved ones.

title: North Korea's calculated silence after failure of martial law in South Korea
summary: South Korea's President Yoon Suk Yeol used the pretext of a North Korean threat to justify his December 3 coup attempt. While there is no evidence to support the claim, the northern neighbor has stayed discreet.

title: Paris Opera in turmoil as dancers strike
summary: Performances of 'Paquita' and 'Play' were canceled after dancers at the Bastille and Garnier Operas went on strike because of a dispute over preparation time ahead of each show.

title: Syrian rebels set Hafez al-Assad's tomb on fire
summary: Rebels set light to the tomb of Hafez al-Assad, the father of the ousted Syrian President Bashar al-Assad, in Qardaha on Wednesday.

title: Macron urges release of Georgian protesters in call with Ivanishvili
summary: In a telephone call the billionaire founder of the Georgian Dream ruling party Bidzina Ivanishvili, President Emmanuel Macron condemned police violence in the government's crackdown on demonstrations in the country.

title: Afghan refugees minister killed in Kabul by suicide blast
summary: Khalil Haqqani was killed in his own ministry's offices. The Taliban government accused the Islamic State organization of being behind the attack.

title: France tells Israel to withdraw its forces from Syria buffer zone
summary: France's foreign ministry urged Israel to stop its incursion into the buffer zone that separates Israeli-controlled Golan Heights from Syria.

title: EU Parliament refuses to pay Jordan Bardella's chief of staff as a parliamentary assistant
summary: Against the backdrop of his party's fake jobs trial, the Rassemblement National's president has had his request for his chief of staff to be hired on a part-time basis rejected.

title: FIFA names Saudi Arabia as host of 2034 World Cup for men's football
summary: Saudi Arabia's confirmation as host of the 2034 World Cup drew criticism from human rights groups. Spain, Portugal and Morocco will co-host the 2030 edition.

title: A bill that would legalize abortion will be debated in Germany's parliament
summary: Green and Social Democrat MPs have introduced a bill that would legalize abortion up to the 12th week of pregnancy.

title: Syria's new government makes first steps, searching for legitimacy
summary: By appointing Mohammed al-Bashir as Syria's transitional prime minister on Tuesday, the Islamist group Hayat Tahrir al-Sham seems intent on cementing its control.

title: Video: Saydnaya prison, a symbol of Assad's regime of terror
summary: 'The human slaughterhouse' was the nickname given to Syria's Saydnaya jail, one of the world's worst prisons.

title: Russia vows retaliation after Ukrainian strike
summary: Russia accused Ukraine of firing missiles that were supplied by the US in an overnight attack on a military airfield.

title: Where French court's arrest warrant for Bashar al-Assad and other Syrian proceedings stand
summary: To date, 13 arrest warrants have been issued, including one for the former dictator, who is now a refugee in Russia.

title: Under Prigozhin's son, Wagner preserves roles in the Central African Republic and Mali
summary: Since the death of Yevgeny Prigozhin, Moscow has been trying to merge the Russian paramilitary group's African nebula into a new organization called 'Africa Corps.' But the mercenaries are continuing their business and military operations in Bangui and Bamako, where they are still favored by the leaders.

title: FBI director Christopher Wray to step down in January
summary: Christopher Wray was chosen by Donald Trump during his last presidential term – but the president-elect has made no secrets of the fact that he would make a new pick come the start of his term in January.

title: Audrey Fleurot: 'I wasted time not loving myself'
summary: 'I wouldn't have got here if...' Every week, 'Le Monde' interviews a public figure about a decisive moment in their life. Audrey Fleurot, an actress known for her TV roles, pays tribute to her parents, who gave free rein to her ambition.

title: Paris 2024 Olympics: Organizing Committee closes accounts with a surplus
summary: The Organizing Committee of the Paris 2024 Olympic and Paralympic Games will present its final multi-year budget to the board of directors on Thursday. It will announce a surplus of at least €26.8 million.
